Israel,
Boston
Massachusetts,
speaking at a discussion on JewishChristian relations, last Monday in
the Sherwood room, Levering hall,
declared, "The explanation of the
rise of Fascism must be sought in a
flight from life and maturity which
is understandable if we remember
how long every human being remains
a child. The child is free from responsibility and therefore relieved of
freedom, namely, the freedom of his
choice. His decisions are made for
him, his health is guarded, his food
is given, his shelter is provided. He
has security."
According to Rabbi Liebman, totalitarianism hates religion, they are
secular substitutes for religion. If
one believes in the high ideals of
Christianity, he cannot be putty to
mold in the hands of a Hitler; therefore National Socialism must do
away with all sacred beliefs. Fascism
negates the quest for truth. Only democracy fosters the high idealism
under which religion can flourish.
Rabbi Liebman closed the discussion by saying that Fascism is desired in this country by some groups
of people and that when Fascism
comes it will be disguised as a movement to save America from National
Socialism.

a tour of New England's best
Christian seminaries. He has studied
at the University of Jerusalem and is
a 'graduate of Hebrew Union college.

It started away back in the thirteenth century at
the University of Paris. Oxford adopted it, and Cambridge took over from Oxford. John Harvard went to
Cambridge, and installed the system at Harvard. American universities followed suit. And so was born and
preserved the tradition of four year schooling courses.
Four years .of high school, then four years of college ..
Well, seven centuries should have been long enough
to firmly establish any tradition, for better or for worse.
It was established all right, but President Goodnow
thought for worse . .

//The Goodnow plan //

The post-war period put the finishing touch on
the question. Between 1916 and 1925 the number of
students in Baltimore high schools, as well as in secondschools throughout the state was fithre-tliati aoulAcel;
the number of Hopkins undergraduates jumped from
about 250 to 750. While there was no objection to
having young men pursue their bachelor's degree,
it was decided that a choice must be made at the Hopkins: should the University attempt to turn out as many
"educated" men as it could; or should it concentrate
on advanced collegiate and post-graduate work, limiting its numbers? Considering all factors, influenced
by the beginnings of the "rah-rah" era, and bearing
in mind that President Gilman originally founded the
undergraduate school merely as an aid to those men
who might need some extra training prior to their entrance into graduate school, the Board of Trustees
passed the "Goodnow plan". The A B degree was to
be ultimately abandoned, and the first two years of
college eliminated. Junior colleges were counted on to
fill the gap. Men were to be trained for higher studies,
with the Bachelor's degree held an unnecessary superfluity.
This in essence was the radical "Goodnow plan". And
in it may be found much of the thought which characterized Dr Goodnow.
Many factors contributed to the failure of the complete execution of the plan. The depression played its
full part. But although the plan was widely discussed
and has been most severely criticized, its fundamental
soundness has withstood all of this .This very soundness partakes of the character and wisdom of its proponent. Dr. Goodnow was an idealist who believed that
all human problems were capable of solution when the
scope of knowledge had been sufficiently extended, but
he never lost sight of practicalities.

Dr Goodnow, the Man

Unusual Tributes
Unusual tributes accorded Dr Goodnow further attest to the esteem in which he was held. A festschrift, a
collection of scholarly essays from former students,
dedicated to him, and a rare touching tribute in the
form of a public, printed expression from the heads
of all divisions of the University, presented at the 50th
Anniversary Celebration still bear witness to this.
Discussions galore from every imaginable type of
publication further describe his charming personality,
and pleasant manner. Not a brilliant public speaker,
Dr Goodnow was more at home with a group of students than before a large gathering. His office was a
wailing wall for all University students. There they felt
at home, as the President tilted his chair and planted
his feet on the long, shining desk. He endeavored to
meet and know as many students as possible, that he
might understand their problems first hand.

At the Age of Seventy
At the age of seventy, too, Dr Goodnow began to
feel that he was approaching his alloted span, whereupon he resigned, his resignation to become effective
upon the appointment of his successor. When Dr Ames
took over, he retired and withdrew from most of his
public life.
Dr Goodnow passed away at his winter home on 911
Poplar hill road on the 15th of this month, after three
years of bad health. His last years were spent quietly,
but his fame still loudly proclaimed the man.

Today and Yesterday
It is interesting to compare aspects of our present
scholastic life with that under Dr Goodnow. Two main
points immediately suggest themselves:
Today, thanks to changes in administrative policy,
the undergraduate school is a firmly established part
of the University. It grows and increases in stature
yearly. The "Goodnow plan" has left and the evils of
the two transitional periods are all but overcome.
The second matter. however, we believe less favorable. In the same letter to the NEWS-LETTER, Dr Goodnow made the comment: "I sincerely trust that when
we do begin our work together I may secure the confidence of the Hopkins students. Their cooperation is
absolutely essential to success ...
The preponderant majority of Hopkins students
cherish certain ideals concerning the University, which
they are both anxious and willing to support. In this
respect, we have not changed. But if two parties are
to cooperate, both must understand what is expected of
them. Blind cooperation is not to be expected in a
community of educated, supposedly alert young men.
We have in mind several happenings of comparative
recent dates. The resignation of Broadus Mitchell and
the rejection of Edward Lewis are two examples. The
attendant agitation in both cases was to be expected.
The administration says, in the case of Lewis, "race
is no factor". Yet here is a man, who admittedly has all
requisites and is nevertheless rejected. Why? The reasons must exist, yet they are not revealed. Again why?
Likewise with Broadus Mitchell. All questions could
have been answered, but weren't. Why?
We who are anxious to defend our University find
it difficult in view of our dearth of facts. The Administration could imbue the student body with a new spirit
were it to cooperate with them as it expects the students to. The student body is the University's most ardent and sympathetic champion, but it must be given a
chance.

It started away back in the thirteenth century at
the University of Paris. Oxford adopted it, and Cambridge took over from Oxford. John Harvard went to
Cambridge, and installed the system at Harvard. American universities followed suit. And so was born and
preserved the tradition of four year schooling courses.
Four years .of high school, then four years of college ..
Well, seven centuries should have been long enough
to firmly establish any tradition, for better or for worse.
It was established all right, but President Goodnow
thought for worse . .

//The Goodnow plan //

The post-war period put the finishing touch on
the question. Between 1916 and 1925 the number of
students in Baltimore high schools, as well as in secondschools throughout the state was fithre-tliati aoulAcel;
the number of Hopkins undergraduates jumped from
about 250 to 750. While there was no objection to
having young men pursue their bachelor's degree,
it was decided that a choice must be made at the Hopkins: should the University attempt to turn out as many
"educated" men as it could; or should it concentrate
on advanced collegiate and post-graduate work, limiting its numbers? Considering all factors, influenced
by the beginnings of the "rah-rah" era, and bearing
in mind that President Gilman originally founded the
undergraduate school merely as an aid to those men
who might need some extra training prior to their entrance into graduate school, the Board of Trustees
passed the "Goodnow plan". The A B degree was to
be ultimately abandoned, and the first two years of
college eliminated. Junior colleges were counted on to
fill the gap. Men were to be trained for higher studies,
with the Bachelor's degree held an unnecessary superfluity.
This in essence was the radical "Goodnow plan". And
in it may be found much of the thought which characterized Dr Goodnow.
Many factors contributed to the failure of the complete execution of the plan. The depression played its
full part. But although the plan was widely discussed
and has been most severely criticized, its fundamental
soundness has withstood all of this .This very soundness partakes of the character and wisdom of its proponent. Dr. Goodnow was an idealist who believed that
all human problems were capable of solution when the
scope of knowledge had been sufficiently extended, but
he never lost sight of practicalities.

Dr Goodnow, the Man

Unusual Tributes
Unusual tributes accorded Dr Goodnow further attest to the esteem in which he was held. A festschrift, a
collection of scholarly essays from former students,
dedicated to him, and a rare touching tribute in the
form of a public, printed expression from the heads
of all divisions of the University, presented at the 50th
Anniversary Celebration still bear witness to this.
Discussions galore from every imaginable type of
publication further describe his charming personality,
and pleasant manner. Not a brilliant public speaker,
Dr Goodnow was more at home with a group of students than before a large gathering. His office was a
wailing wall for all University students. There they felt
at home, as the President tilted his chair and planted
his feet on the long, shining desk. He endeavored to
meet and know as many students as possible, that he
might understand their problems first hand.

At the Age of Seventy
At the age of seventy, too, Dr Goodnow began to
feel that he was approaching his alloted span, whereupon he resigned, his resignation to become effective
upon the appointment of his successor. When Dr Ames
took over, he retired and withdrew from most of his
public life.
Dr Goodnow passed away at his winter home on 911
Poplar hill road on the 15th of this month, after three
years of bad health. His last years were spent quietly,
but his fame still loudly proclaimed the man.

Today and Yesterday
It is interesting to compare aspects of our present
scholastic life with that under Dr Goodnow. Two main
points immediately suggest themselves:
Today, thanks to changes in administrative policy,
the undergraduate school is a firmly established part
of the University. It grows and increases in stature
